topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Garrett previews the once-in-a-lifetime AI demand moment; Lenny introduces Handshake’s original business and the new AI data business that rapidly scaled to massive ARR.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for CodeRabbit and Orkes.

topics.title: What data labeling is and why it matters
topics.summary: Garrett explains model training at a high level and why post-training data has become the main driver of frontier model improvements as pre-training gains plateau.

topics.title: Post-training methods: RLHF, SFT, trajectories
topics.summary: They clarify post-training buckets (RLHF preference ranking, supervised fine-tuning, reasoning data) and why labs are experimenting with multiple evolving data types.

topics.title: Handshake’s edge: experts over generalists
topics.summary: Garrett describes Handshake’s engaged network (PhDs, masters, global students) and argues the market shifted from low-cost generalists to domain experts to push models forward.

topics.title: Creating new data and breaking models
topics.summary: Handshake helps generate novel expert data and identify model weaknesses that average users can’t surface, especially in advanced STEM and professional domains.

topics.title: What experts do day-to-day (GPQA example)
topics.summary: Garrett walks through how experts craft hard questions, provide ground truth and step-by-step reasoning, and pinpoint where non-deterministic models fail.

topics.title: Non-verifiable domains and human tool-use capture
topics.summary: They discuss domains without single right answers (e.g., education), plus collecting ‘trajectory’ data via screen/mouse/voice to teach models how humans solve real workflows.

topics.title: Data formats, multimodal work, and rubric judging
topics.summary: Garrett notes outputs like structured JSON, describes multimodal labeling (audio/music), and explains rubric-based evaluation where models can act as judges for subjective tasks.

topics.title: What labs optimize for: quality, volume, speed
topics.summary: Garrett outlines the three core buyer requirements and how Handshake uses assessment, post-training expertise, and fast iteration to deliver reliable gains.

topics.title: Humans in the loop and jobs impact debate
topics.summary: They discuss why humans will remain necessary for years, and debate AI’s impact on entry-level jobs—Garrett argues AI boosts productivity and shifts skills rather than eliminating work.

topics.title: Market dynamics and Scale’s acquisition implications
topics.summary: Garrett comments on competitive concerns when a data provider is tied to a peer lab, and argues the key moat is audience access and trust, not just recruiting spend.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Anthropic’s Claude and its workflow integrations.

topics.title: Origin story: launching the new AI data business
topics.summary: Garrett explains how middlemen demand and direct outreach from frontier labs revealed the opportunity; he describes building a specialized team and scaling to work with seven labs.

topics.title: Handshake core business and AI-era unfair advantage
topics.summary: Garrett summarizes Handshake’s 10-year student career platform, why it differs from LinkedIn for early-career users, and how its trusted network enabled rapid expansion into AI data.

topics.title: How expert data platforms recruit and retain talent
topics.summary: They compare legacy approaches (recruiters + ads) with Handshake’s community/training model, emphasizing better expert experience, higher retention, and structural CAC/LTV advantages.

topics.title: Incubating business two inside business one
topics.summary: Garrett begins describing the tactical early steps—working with middlemen, seeing demand signals, and receiving direct lab outreach—setting up the next part of the story.
